A.definition: What term describes the state of a product being in stock?
hints: If the shelf is full, this is high.
Opposite of 'out of stock'.
Often measured as a percentage on-shelf.
Starts with A and ends with 'bility'.

B.definition: In our strategy, we aim to make our net sales and GP1…?
hints: The strategy is about growth, not shrinking.
Comparative form of the word 'big'.
Appears on our slides together with 'better'.
Starts with B and has 6 letters.

C.definition: In what phase in the sales funnel does a customer complete a purchase?
hints: It’s the moment when a visitor becomes a buyer.
A key metric in ecommerce performance.
Often expressed as a rate or percentage.
Starts with C and is followed by 'rate' in many dashboards.

D.definition: In Power BI, data is displayed in a…
hints: A visual overview of KPIs and charts.
You can pin tiles and reports here.
Named after the control panel in a car.
Starts with D and ends with 'board'.

E.definition: Which metric refers to the level of interaction users have with content, such as clicks, comments, or shares?
hints: Likes, shares, and comments all contribute to this.
High values usually mean your content resonates.
Often tracked on social media and retail media.
Starts with E and ends with 'ment'.

F.definition: A framework describing a self-reinforcing loop that drives growth.
hints: Popularized by modern growth and marketing models.
Customer delight feeds momentum in this model.
Opposite of a linear funnel; it keeps spinning.
Starts with F and includes the word 'wheel'.

G.definition: P&L line before the marketing budget is subtracted.
hints: It comes after net sales, before marketing expenses.
A key measure of product profitability.
Shown as the first gross profit line in P&L.
Starts with G and is often written with a '1'.

H.definition: Visual representation of user behavior on a webpage by showing where people click, scroll, or hover most.
hints: Hotter colors usually mean more activity.
Used to optimize layout, buttons and CTAs.
Helps you see what parts of a page attract attention.
Starts with H and contains the word 'heat'.
Internal platform supporting innovative ideas for packs and products.
Name combines 'innovation' and 'packaging'.
Used to collaborate on new concepts.
Starts with I and ends with 'pack'.

J.definition: Term for the complete path a consumer follows across multiple touchpoints, from first awareness to purchase.
hints: Covers all steps from awareness to loyalty.
Includes online and offline touchpoints.
Mapped to understand friction and opportunities.
Starts with J and often follows the word 'customer'.

K.definition: Specific words or phrases users type into search engines to find content or products.
hints: Critical for SEO and marketplace search.
You bid on these in paid search campaigns.
Choosing the right ones boosts visibility.
Starts with K and ends with 'words'.

L.definition: Term for a contact who has shown interest in a product or service and shared their information, but has not yet purchased.
hints: Marketing and sales teams work together to qualify this.
Can be warm, cold, or hot.
You hope to convert this into a customer.
Four letters, starts with L.

M.definition: Abbreviation which refers to the set of essential products that should always be available on shelves.
hints: Defines the core items that must not be missing.
Used by sales reps and category managers.
Ensures shoppers always find key products.
Three-letter acronym starting with M.

M.definition: The expected profit from a sale.
hints: Difference between selling price and cost.
Can be expressed in % or in currency.
You always want this to be healthy, not zero.
Six letters and starts with M.

N.definition: To find information and products one can use the search bar or the…
hints: Often appears as a bar or menu at the top of a site.
Good design here helps users find categories quickly.
Breadcrumbs and menus are part of this.
Starts with N and is key to user experience.

O.definition: What strategy integrates multiple sales and communication channels into one seamless customer experience?
hints: Bridges online and offline shopping journeys.
Customer should feel it’s one brand, not many channels.
Click & collect is part of this strategy.
Starts with O and contains the word 'channel'.

P.definition: Amazon, bol.com, Rohlik and Allegro are…
hints: They operate only online, not with physical stores.
Often marketplaces or quick-commerce platforms.
Opposite of 'brick-and-mortar' retailers.
Starts with P and includes the word 'player'.

Q.definition: Wolt, Getir, Zapp, Glovo are offering …. commerce.
hints: Promises delivery in minutes, not days.
Often focused on convenience baskets and top-up trips.
Uses dark stores or local hubs for speed.
Two words: first starts with Q, second with C.
Customers notice this in performance and reliability.
QA and QC teams test and monitor it.
We always aim to increase this, not reduce it.
Starts with Q and ends with Y.

R.definition: Metric in Retail Media indicating how many unique users or households were exposed to a campaign's ads.
hints: Different from frequency, which counts repetitions.
Higher values mean more people saw the campaign at least once.
Often shown together with impressions and GRPs.
Five letters and starts with R.

S.definition: What practice focuses on improving a website’s or product's visibility in organic search results?
hints: Helps you rank higher without paying for each click.
Works with keywords, content, and technical improvements.
Three-letter acronym is very well known to marketers.
Full term starts with S, E, and O.

T.definition: What term refers to the number of visitors a website receives over a given period?
hints: You usually want more of this, as long as it’s relevant.
Can be organic, paid, or direct.
Analytics tools track this for sites.
Also a word for cars on the road.

U.definition: Abbreviation for the overall experience and satisfaction a user has when interacting with a website, app, or any other digital touchpoint.
hints: Closely linked to usability and design.
Good versions of this make products easy and enjoyable to use.
Often paired with UI in digital projects.
Two-letter acronym: first letter is U.

V.definition: Term for how easily a product can be discovered in online and offline stores.
hints: If shoppers can’t see it, they can’t buy it.
Planograms and search rankings both affect this.
Share-of-shelf and share-of-search link to it.
Starts with V and ends with 'bility'.

W.definition: Platform used to share eCommerce Best Practices.
hints: Internal platform for learning and best-practice sharing.
Name combines 'we' and a verb about getting bigger.
Focuses strongly on eCommerce capabilities.
Starts with W and ends with 'grow'.

X.definition: (Contains X) What standard of quality do we strive for in everything we do?
hints: Goes beyond 'good' and even beyond 'very good'.
Often paired with 'operational' or 'commercial'.
Contains the letter X near the beginning.
Ten letters, starts with E.

Y.definition: Acronym referring to data covering beginning of the year to the current date.
hints: Often compared with last year’s same period.
Used in financial and performance dashboards.
Stands for 'Year To Date'.
Three-letter acronym starting with Y.

Z.definition: (Contains Z) Tool found in the Collaboration Toolbox to generate consumer feedback.
hints: Used for user testing and consumer insights.
Lets you collect feedback on websites or concepts.
Name starts with 'User' and includes the idea of 'zooming in'.
Contains the letter Z in the middle.

Z.definition: The approach that requires justifying each decision or budget line individually, rather than basing it on the previous period.
hints: Every period starts from a 'clean slate'.
Nothing is automatically carried over from last year.
Often abbreviated as ZBB.
Starts with Z and ends with 'budgeting'.
